physDesc.p: The letter consists of three sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. The final page has only a little bit of writing at the top and is mostly empty. The edges of the pages have some bent areas, and there are a few areas where someone has handwritten edits or scratched out words.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I feel very badly indeed to have raised your hopes to the pitch evidenced by your letter of December 28th. I sent you a cable yesterday to disabuse your mind of their being any immediate prospect of our having a paper here. In my letter of December 15th, I wrote you saying that I would try to raise the money, if you cared to consider the job of editorship, and I told you that I had only got one subscriber then. I do not know what Fletcher may have written you, but you should know by this time that he is very enthusiastic and utopian, and not to be taken au pied de la lettre. I fear he must have given you the idea that there was more immediate chance of our being able to raise the money for the paper than there was.

Since I wrote to you, I have been feeling round a little; and since receiving your letter I have asked for some subscriptions, always somehow however with the same disheartening result. Nobody feels like giving anything just now, and I do not know whether they will after the War, but I am bound to confess that the prospects are not bright.

There has been a multiplication of little papers devoted to poetry since Harriet started here. Another one, called “Contemporary Verse,” has issued its first number since I wrote to you. It is very poor, but all these things have tended to make people skeptical on with the advisability of helping small magazines. And the big ones, which have much greater expenses, are failing right and left. You seem somehow to have got an inflated idea of my intentions in regard to this paper. To run such a paper as you suggest, on such lines as you suggest, would take an amount of money which I could never hope to command. “The New Republic” is endowed with $50,000 a year, and then I understand it does not pay, although they have 10,000 subscribers. Everything is on a larger scale here than in England. The country not having any one particular centre, magazines printed in one part of it are frequently not to be found on the news-stands of another.It is impossible to get “Reedy’s Mirror” of St. Louis on any news-stand in the East, or the San Francisco “Argonaut” or the “Bellman.” All this makes the proposition a much more difficult one. I have been looking into it a little more since I wrote you, and I am very sorry indeed that I did not look into it more carefully before I even hinted to you that such an idea had entered my head. It seems quite impossible for us to attempt such a thing, even if we could raise the money. It never occurred to me that you would have an idea of branching out into an office, and a stenographer, and an office boy. Of course, I knew those things to be out of the question. No stenographer could be got for less than $65.00 a month, which you will easily see would be utterly beyond our capacity to pay. I supposed that you would be willing to do the clerical work and send out the magazine once a month, as you do the Poet’s Translation Series, and it seemed to me that your salary should be determined with a view to that. In this, it seems, I was mistaken. I can perfectly understand our point of view, but I can equally see the impossibility of anything of the sort.

Another thing is your desire to be the editor-in-chief, the court of final appeal. That, of course, you can see would not be possible. If we succeeded in raising any money, the people who gave it to us would give it on the guarantee of my character and my point of view. They do not know you, and your name would carry no weight over here at first. I should therefore be responsible to the people who gave us the money; and under those circumstances, it would be absolutely imperative that I should have the final say, and assume, in fact, the full responsibility. I should not expect to interfere with you any more than was absolutely necessary; but I should certainly direct the policy of the paper, and I am afraid I should not direct it upon strictly Imagistic lines. We could not have any paper if we did, because there are not enough Imagists to write for it. I suppose, really, it would be only exchanging Miss Weaver for me, and although I imagine that you would not have such difficulty with me as you have with Miss Weaver, still it would be working in a subordinate position, although I do not think that you would feel that very much.

Another point you mention is the running of propaganda for the Allies in the paper. That would be quite out of the question. In the first place, I do not think there ought to be any political articles of any kind in the paper. A great many papers and magazines are already devoted to matters of international and national import. We are in no way fitted to write upon political subjects. We should do it amateurishly and badly and make ourselves ridiculous. And there is another difficulty, and that is that although a great many people here are, as you know, in favour of the Allies, there are also a vast quantity in America who are pro-German. Just here in Boston, most of the people one knows are pro-Ally, and you know how pro-Ally I am myself. But what Europeans very rarely realize is that, in spite of individual opinions, the country as a whole is neutral, really neutral, in the sense that each side neutralizes the other. I do not myself believe it is possible for us to go to war on either side, because I think there are enough sympathizers on the other side in Congress to prevent our declaring war. Under these circumstances, we are obliged to maintain a certain elasticity and courtesy in our daily life. I personally have given up sending any poems of mine to “The International,” because Mr. Viereck is so violently pro-German, and his other paper, “The Fatherland,” is the official paper for hyphenated Americans. He has been peculiarly blatant and offensive. But there are many other papers which are distinctly Germanistic in leaning, although they wisely refrain from polemics in which my poems appear and those of other people. If you come to this country, you will find yourself constantly thrown with Germans and German sympathizers, and it will be necessary to treat them as calmly and as pleasantly as if there were no war. We could not possibly antagonize all the German sympathizers by running any propaganda whatever. I think we should remain completely out of the field of politics. This is not difficult here. We have had much practice. One of my most intimate friends is German, and he sympathizes with the German cause; he dines with me frequently, and although we avoid speaking of the War as much as possible, when we do, we do it quite naturally and without heat. The Poetry Society of America, at whose meetings the poems are read aloud, have pro-Ally and pro-German poems follow each other, and the poems are discussed on their merits and not at all upon their political bearings. So you see how really neutral the country at large is. The war is also comparatively far from here, and it is really quite easy to avoid it. But the idea of writing running any political propaganda in a literary and artistic paper is one I should not consent to for a moment.

Another objection is that you could not possibly put on your passport that you were coming over here to edit such a paper. I do not think you would be allowed to land. I do not think that the Government would allow such an obviously partisan movement. In the second place, there is a law in this country, called the Contract Labour Law or some such name, by which people are not allowed to be engaged for a job before they leave their country. It is of course aimed at day labourers and factory hands, but I think I am right in saying that it holds good for everybody. The way it is got round is that people do not announce their engagements upon stepping ashore. But if you had it in your passort, I think that it would dish you completely. Also the idea of having anything so grave attached to so simple a little sheet as ours, would be would cause a burst of amusement from all the newspapers in the country, and we should be black-eyed before we started.

I have now answered your remarks at length, and I am afraid I have given you the impression that it is very little use for us to try to run a paper, even if we had the money. As a matter of fact, we have not the money, and I do not believe we can get it, so it is really unnecessary to discuss these minor details until we have. I only put them in, in order that you might realize exactly what the situation was, and what it would be, before you took a jump in the dark. It would be the greatest pleasure to have you and Hilda here, and I think we should have a heavenly time with all of us in Boston together, but the rebuffs I have received at the suggestion that anybody should give any money for such a paper, have considerably dampened my ardour. People are always very anxious to pat you on the back and tell you how sympathetic they are until you suggest touching their pocket-books, and then it is extraordinary what a number of reasons they have against their being subscribers. I am afraid we shall all just have to put it out of our minds for the moment, which is quite as much of a disappointment to Fletcher and me as it is to you. I am awfully sorry if what either Fletcher or I said led you to think the scheme was more than a vague outline based entirely upon hope. If I am ever able to raise the money, at some future date, I trust that the scheme as I have outlined it more fully will appeal to you, because I think the thing should be put down in legal black and white before we start, so there should be no misunderstandings at any rate. I did not go into all these details before, as the whole thing seemed so up in the air; but since you have raised the questions, I thought I had better answer them at length. I am just as sorry as I can be that people are so close-fisted. But what can we do?
